title: Marjorie Taylor Greene
categories: Opposition to Islam in the United States
Candidates in the 2020 United States elections

sentences.text: Marjorie Taylor Greene (born May 27, 1974) is an American politician and businesswoman from the state of Georgia.
She is the Republican nominee for in the 2020 elections.

links.page: 2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Georgia

sentences.text: She came to prominence for her public support of QAnon in Facebook videos.
She later distanced herself from the conspiracy theory.

image.text: Marjorie Greene on Unite America First.jpg

sentences.text: Greene was born in Milledgeville, Georgia, on May 27, 1974.
She graduated from South Forsyth High School in Cumming, Georgia, and the University of Georgia with a bachelor's degree in business administration.

references.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene: How an Outspoken MAGA Fan Built a Following in a World of Extremists

sentences.text: Greene began her 2020 candidacy in, but shifted her campaign to the 14th district after incumbent Tom Graves announced he would not run for reelection.
In the days before the primary election, Facebook took down a Greene advertisement in which she brandished an AR-15 style rifle for violating its terms of service.
Greene finished in first place in the primary election and faced John Cowan in the runoff election.
Greene defeated Cowan to win the nomination on August 11.
Greene is considered an overwhelming favorite to win the seat in the general election, as the 14th typically votes heavily Republican.
If she wins election, she will be the second Republican woman to represent Georgia in the House, and the first to be elected to a full term.
Karen Handel was elected to represent the neighboring 6th District in a special election in 2017, but was defeated for a full term in 2018.

references.title: Marjorie Greene officially shifts campaign to District 14 congressional seat {{!}} Georgia News
Facebook deletes Georgia congressional candidate Marjorie Greene's ad
Marjorie Greene, John Cowan likely headed for runoff in Georgia's 14th Congressional District
Marjorie Taylor Greene, a QAnon Supporter, Wins House Primary in Georgia

sentences.text: Greene supported the far-right QAnon conspiracy theory, saying in videos posted in 2017 on Facebook that the theories were "worth listening to".
She posted 57 articles found in the archives of the American Truth Seeker website.
Greene later distanced herself from the conspiracy theory and rejected the label of "QAnon candidate."
She had stated in a video, "There's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to take this global cabal of Satan-worshiping pedophiles out, and I think we have the president to do it."
In a 2017 video posted to Facebook, Greene expressed doubt that the perpetrator of the 2017 Las Vegas shooting acted alone.
She also called George Soros, a Jewish businessman, a Nazi.
After the 2018 midterm elections, Greene stated that the election of Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib was part of "an Islamic invasion of our government."

links.page: 2018 United States House of Representatives elections

sentences.text: In 2018, Greene expressed support for a conspiracy theory that a plane did not hit the Pentagon during the September 11 attacks, saying that "it's odd there's never any evidence shown for a plane in the Pentagon," despite video evidence.
She later admitted on Twitter that the 9/11 conspiracy theory is "not correct."
After the first round of voting in the 2020 election, Politico re-released videos published by Greene in which she expressed racist, antisemitic, and Islamophobic views.
The videos were later condemned by Congressmen Kevin McCarthy and Steve Scalise and received criticism in the media.

sentences.text: Greene and her husband, Perry, have owned Taylor Commercial, a construction company based in Alpharetta, Georgia, since 2002.
